title: Trump calls Pelosi’s impeachment move ‘witch hunt garbage’ and ‘presidential harassment’
text:
President Donald Trump on Tuesday afternoon went on a Twitter tear after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced a formal impeachment inquiry against him.

Trump characterized the congressional move toward impeachment as a distraction and “garbage”:

‘Witch Hunt garbage. So bad for our Country!’

“Such an important day at the United Nations, so much work and so much success, and the Democrats purposely had to ruin and demean it with more breaking news Witch Hunt garbage. So bad for our Country!” Trump said via Twitter minutes after Pelosi’s late-afternoon announcement:

Such an important day at the United Nations, so much work and so much success, and the Democrats purposely had to ruin and demean it with more breaking news Witch Hunt garbage. So bad for our Country! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 24, 2019

The president also referred the latest political development as “presidential harassment” — in capital letters followed by an exclamation point:

Pelosi, a California Democrat who’s serving as speaker of the House for the second time, said “the president must be held accountable.”

“No one,” she said, “is above the law.”

Check out: Why Trump impeachment threat is suddenly rattling stock-market investors

The swift move this week toward impeachment was prompted by a Trump phone call with Ukrainian President Voldomyr Zelensky on July 25. At issue is a whistleblower complaint surrounding Trump’s interaction or interactions with Zelensky.

Trump, it has been reported by the Wall Street Journal, asked his acting chief of staff to withhold some $400 million in military aid to Ukraine as Trump urged the Ukrainian president to investigate the business dealings of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden’s son, Hunter. Democrats, on Wednesday, will vote to condemn the Trump administration for withholding the whistleblower complaint about the president’s Ukraine call.

Trump has played down his dealings with the Ukrainian president and said he plans to release an “unredacted” transcript of the phone conversation on Wednesday. “You will see it was a very friendly and totally appropriate call,” Trump wrote on Twitter earlier Tuesday.

“No pressure and, unlike Joe Biden and his son, NO quid pro quo! This is nothing more than a continuation of the Greatest and most Destructive Witch Hunt of all time!”

....You will see it was a very friendly and totally appropriate call. No pressure and, unlike Joe Biden and his son, NO quid pro quo! This is nothing more than a continuation of the Greatest and most Destructive Witch Hunt of all time! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 24, 2019

The president also tweeted a video montage of Democrats advocating for his impeachment — a goal for many Trump critics amid investigations of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, which was the subject of special counsel Robert Mueller’s now concluded inquiry.

To be sure, impeachment doesn’t translate to removal from office. Most recently, Bill Clinton was impeached by the House in 1998 but acquitted by the Senate. Clinton’s impeachment had very little impact on the stock market.

So far, stock-market reaction to the Pelosi announcement has been subdued in after-hour trading, following a slump amid early reports of her intention to launch a formal inquiry. The Dow DJIA, -0.53% closed lower by 141.81 points, or 0.5%, at 26,806.18, while the benchmark S&P 500 SPX, -0.84% declined 25.16 points, or 0.8%, to 2,966.62. The Nasdaq COMP, -1.46% was off more sharply, surrendering 118.84 points, or 1.5%, to finish the day at 7,993.63.

After the closing bell, however, the SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF Trust DIA, -0.52% was up 0.2% on light volume, the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust SPY, -0.78% was trading flat but narrowly in positive territory, while the Nasdaq-100 NDX, -1.39% was up 1.4%. Futures for the Dow YMZ19, +0.24% , S&P ESZ19, +0.23% and Nasdaq NQZ19, +0.24% weren’t being traded.

description: President Donald Trump on Tuesday afternoon goes on Twitter tirade after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced a formal impeachment inquiry.
